title: HPM 883Spring 2025
text:
HPM 883 is an advanced graduate-level course designed to equip PhD students in the Health Policy and Management program with sophisticated quantitative research skills. This course represents the third installment in the quantitative methods sequence, building on the foundational knowledge acquired in HPM 881 and HPM 882.
Throughout the term, students will delve into advanced quantitative methods pertinent to health services research with a focus on the use of experimental methods and machine learning for causal inference. The course will provide a thorough introduction to machine learning techniques and explore the burgeoning domain of causal machine learning.

title: HPM 883Spring 2025

Throughout the term, students will delve into advanced quantitative methods pertinent to health services research with a focus on the use of experimental methods and machine learning for causal inference. The course will provide a thorough introduction to machine learning techniques and explore the burgeoning domain of causal machine learning.

title: Communication
text:
Slack will be our primary communication hub. An invitation to the course Slack will be shared on the first day of class. Use this place to ask questions, share resources, and engage with your peers, the instructor, and the TA. (For personal matters, please use e-mail)






Important:



Slack will not be continuously monitored by the instructor or TA outside of posted office hours. At other times, students are expected to help/engage with one another to foster a shared learning experience. If a question hasn’t been addressed, the TA or Sean will respond but not immediately or even the same day.
You may DM Sean or the TA in Slack (but, again, don’t expect a response immediately or even the same day.)



The #announcements channel will be used to share course announcements.
Use the #help channel as a first stop for general questions about the class or for technical assistance.
Use the #general channel to discuss lab assignments and discuss/share resources related to course topics.
Use the #interesting-stuff channel to share relevant articles, podcasts, packages, data sources, and anything else relevant that you think your classmates will benefit from.

title: Lab 0
text:
St. Null’s Memorial Hospital is in chaos. Every time the hospital board—led by the well-meaning but trend-obsessed CEO Barnaby Beta—implements a new policy, they find puzzling or contradictory results. Dr. P-Hacker, a self-styled data guru, only adds to the confusion by massaging, cherry-picking, and p-hacking the data until he sees “significance.” Meanwhile, Nurse Random constantly rolls her eyes at his antics and reminds everyone that solid methodology—not creative statistics—should guide decision-making.
But there’s hope. Your class has just been hired as “methodology consultants” to diagnose and treat the hospital’s research woes. In each module (or “episode”), you’ll confront a new fiasco at St. Null’s: from suspiciously overfitted AI models, to missing data nightmares, to bungled randomized trials and flawed observational studies. Along the way, the brilliant but quirky Dr. Doub R. Obust will champion doubly robust methods and other advanced techniques to rescue the day.




Your mission? Use proper causal inference and machine learning strategies to shed light on the true effects of the hospital’s interventions. Each chapter in your lecture notes (i.e., Jupyter notebooks) begins with a brief “scene” in which the hospital staff face some methodological mishap—then shifts to your step-by-step explanation of the relevant statistical concepts and R code. By the end of the course, you’ll have helped St. Null’s Memorial Hospital finally achieve consistent, credible results, while having a bit of comedic fun along the way.

title: Instructors
text:
Sean Sylvia is an Associate Professor in the Department of Health Policy and Management in the Gillings School of Global Public Health at UNC Chapel Hill.
Office Hours: Dr. Sylvia will hold office hours on Wednesdays from 1-2pm. Please book an appointment at least 24 hours ahead of time using this LINK.
